Seven figure sum to boost Leicester City Council coffers after housing land sale By danjmartin | Posted: June 01, 2016 Artist's impression of Ashton Green Seven figure sum to boost Leicester City Council coffers after housing land sale X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
The sale of a plot of land to builders is expected to raise a seven-figure sum for the city council. 
Mayor Sir Peter Soulsby has agreed a deal to sell 2.5 acres of land in Beaumont Leys to Morris Homes. 
The site – Glebelands Wood, off Leicester Road – has been earmarked as part of the planned Ashton Green development to the north west of the city. 
The council has been seeking developers to construct the 3,000-home estate and Sir Peter said the agreement would dispose of the first of five parcels of building land. 
Read more: Liberal Democrat Leicestershire councillor on pro-Brexit campaign trail 
He said: "This will be a major disposal and it is the first significant sale in the Ashton Green project. 
"The deal will be dependent on planning permission being granted and until that stage we cannot put figures in the public domain." 
Outline planning permission for the 320-acre site was granted in 2011 but detailed designs still require approval. 
The council struggled to sell the whole site to a single developer, as it originally intended, as firms were wary of taking on the entire project. 
Read more: No further police action against Britain First leader Paul Golding following Leicester arrest 
The council then rethought the overall plan by sub-dividing the site and it also agreed to invest in infrastructure, such as roads, in advance to make it a more attractive prospect.Such costs are usually met by the developers. 
The whole site, bordered on the north west by the A46, is expected to consist of up to 3,000 homes, including lower-cost housing, as well as parks, employment land, schools, community and health facilities. 
Key priorities include safe routes for pedestrians and cyclists, good public transport connections and 124 acres of green space. 
Ashton Green will also be served by buses from an early stage. 
The entire development will take place over the next 20 years.The @sale of a plot of land to builders is expected to raise a seven-figure sum for the city council.
